title: Understanding Insulin Resistance: What Your Morning Glucose Really Tells You | Carnivore Weekly
author: Carnivore Weekly
description: Decode your fasting glucose numbers and calculate your HOMA-IR score to understand insulin resistance. Learn why 'normal' ranges miss early metabolic dysfunction and what your morning reading actually reveals.
content_html:
TL;DR

  • Optimal fasting glucose is 70-85 mg/dL ‚Äî "normal" ranges (under 100) miss early insulin resistance by 15+ points
  • Your liver controls morning glucose ‚Äî elevated readings happen because insulin-resistant livers ignore the "stop producing glucose" signal
  • Calculate your HOMA-IR score ‚Äî (glucose √ó insulin) / 405 reveals true insulin sensitivity that fasting glucose alone can't show
  • This is reversible ‚Äî dietary changes can drop HOMA-IR from 2.8 to 1.3 in 6 months

You wake up, prick your finger, and see 105 mg/dL on your glucometer. Is that good? Bad? Should you worry?

Here's the thing: your fasting glucose isn't just a random number. It's a window into how your body handles energy while you sleep‚Äîand it can reveal insulin resistance years before you'd ever be diagnosed with prediabetes or type 2 diabetes.

What "Normal" Actually Means (And Why It's Misleading)

The official guidelines say fasting glucose under 100 mg/dL is "normal." But research suggests insulin resistance often starts developing when fasting glucose creeps above 85 mg/dL. That's a 15-point gap where your body might be struggling, but conventional medicine isn't flagging it yet.

I've seen this in my own health journey. When my fasting glucose sat around 95 mg/dL, my doctor said everything looked fine. But I felt tired, struggled with afternoon energy crashes, and couldn't lose weight despite eating well. Once I dug into my insulin levels, the picture became clear: my fasting insulin was 12 ¬µIU/mL. That combination gave me a HOMA-IR score of 2.8‚Äîwell into insulin resistance territory.

"Your fasting glucose shows you the tip of the iceberg. Fasting insulin reveals what's happening beneath the surface."

Why Morning Glucose Rises (Even When You Don't Eat)

You might think, "I didn't eat anything overnight, so why isn't my glucose lower?" The answer is your liver.

While you sleep, your liver releases stored glucose to keep your brain and body running. This is totally normal‚Äîit's called hepatic glucose output.

But when you're insulin resistant, your liver doesn't respond properly to insulin's signal to "stop making glucose." So it keeps pumping out more than you need, and your morning number climbs higher than it should.

This is why someone with insulin resistance can wake up with a fasting glucose of 110 mg/dL even after eating a perfect carnivore dinner the night before. It's not about what you ate‚Äîit's about how your metabolism is functioning at a cellular level.

The HOMA-IR Test: Your Real Insulin Sensitivity Score

Fasting glucose alone doesn't tell the whole story. You need to pair it with fasting insulin to calculate your HOMA-IR (Homeostatic Model Assessment of Insulin Resistance).

When I calculated mine (fasting glucose 95, fasting insulin 12), I got 2.8. That explained everything‚Äîthe fatigue, the weight plateau, the brain fog. My body was producing too much insulin just to keep my glucose in that "normal" range.

Fasting insulin isn't part of standard bloodwork. You'll need to specifically request it. Don't accept "your glucose is fine" without knowing both numbers. The combination reveals metabolic problems 5-10 years before glucose alone would flag them.

What to Do If Your Numbers Show Insulin Resistance

If your fasting glucose sits above 90 mg/dL or your HOMA-IR is above 2.0, here's what actually works:

1

Prioritize Protein, Eliminate Processed Carbs

Non-negotiable. Insulin resistance improves dramatically when you remove foods that spike insulin repeatedly. Going full carnivore dropped my fasting glucose from 95 to 82 mg/dL in 8 weeks.

2

Track Fasting Insulin, Not Just Glucose

Ask your doctor to order a fasting insulin test alongside your glucose. It's a standard blood test‚Äîmost just don't suggest it automatically. You need both numbers for the full picture.

3

Retest in 8-12 Weeks

Insulin sensitivity doesn't improve overnight. Give your body time to adapt, then recheck your HOMA-IR score. You'll see fasting insulin drop first, then glucose follows.

"Insulin resistance isn't a life sentence. It's feedback. Your body is telling you something needs to change, and it will respond when you give it the right inputs."

Why This Matters for Long-Term Health

Insulin resistance doesn't just affect your energy or weight. It's the root cause of metabolic syndrome and drives progression toward serious disease.

Insulin resistance damages blood vessels and promotes inflammation, increasing heart attack and stroke risk.

Researchers call Alzheimer's "type 3 diabetes" because of its direct link to brain insulin resistance.

High blood pressure, elevated triglycerides, low HDL, and visceral fat‚Äîall driven by insulin dysregulation.

The end stage of unchecked insulin resistance. Preventable with early intervention.

Catching insulin resistance early‚Äîbefore your glucose hits prediabetic levels‚Äîgives you a massive advantage. Your body can reverse course. I've watched my own HOMA-IR drop from 2.8 to 1.3 over 6 months by changing how I eat and prioritizing metabolic health.
